facts.text: Appeal by special leave from award dated May 19, 1967 of Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad in Adjudication Case No. 15 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1734 of 1967. Appeal by Special Leave from the Award dated the May 19, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal  1  at Allahabad in Adjudication Case No. 15 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant is a limited liability company carrying on business of generation, distribution and supply of electricity at Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, which is a limited liability companypany and which later on went into voluntary liquidation, was carrying on the business or undertaking of generation, distribution and supply of electricity.

facts.text: Appellant's Electric Supply Undertaking at Allahabad managed by Martin Burn Co. Ltd., Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: One of such undertakings was the Electric Supply Undertaking at Allahabad in the State of Uttar Pradesh. Its affairs and business were being looked after and managed by Martin Bum Co. I-Ad., Calcutta.

facts.text: Some workmen members of Bijli Mazdoor Sangh, registered trade union.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the appellants workmen in Allahabad and its surrounding area were members of Bijli Mazdoor Sangh-a trade union registered under the Indian Trade Union Act, 1926.

facts.text: U.P. State Electricity Board compulsorily acquired appellant's undertaking effective from 16/17th September 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The U.P. State Electricity Board companypulsorily acquired and took over the assets of the appellants aforesaid undertaking or business with effect from 16/17th September 1964.

facts.text: Appellant submitted draft Standing Orders under Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act 1946, certified by Certifying Officer on July 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the provisions of the Industrial, Employment  Standing Orders  Act 1946, hereinafter called the Act and the U.P. Industrial Employment  Standing Orders  Rules 1946 the appellant submitted draft Standing Orders defining the companyditions of employment of its employees. On July 14, 1951 these Orderswere certified by the Certifying Officer.

facts.text: Clause 32 of certified Standing Orders: employee retired after 30 years service or age 55, exemption possible.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 32 of the Standing Orders was in the following terms - RETIREMENT-An employee who has served 30 years or who has reached the age of 55 will be retired, but exemption to this may be granted by the Company in-special cases.

facts.text: Workmen through Bijli Mazdoor Sangh appealed certification to State Industrial Tribunal, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen through the Bijli Mazdoor Sangh preferred an appeal under s. 6 of the Act from the order of  the Certifying Officer to the State Industrial Tribunal which was the. appellate authority under the Act. That appeal, however,, was dismissed.

facts.text: Notices served on seven workmen on July 16, 1959 to retire effective September 1, 1959 on ground of superannuation.

anchor.surface_text: On July 16, 1959 numberices were served on seven worlen with effect from September 1, 1959 on the ground that they had attained the age of superannuation or companypleted 30 years of service and they were retired by reason of their having attained the age of superannuation.

facts.text: One of seven workmen, Haider Ali, died during pendency of proceedings; other six are respondents Nos. 1 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these workmen one of them Haider Ali died during the pendency of proceedings. The other six employees have been impleaded as respondents Nos. 1 to 6 in the present appeal.

facts.text: Respondents accepted provident fund accumulations and gratuities.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant these, respondents accepted all the accumulations due to them in respect of Provident Fund companytributions made by the appellant in respect of them and by themselves and were also paid gratuities credited to them in their res- pective Provident Fund accounts for their services prior to their becoming members of the Provident Fund.

facts.text: Government of U.P. referred industrial dispute to Industrial Tribunal Allahabad on February 22, 1960 under s.4-K U.P. Industrial Disputes Act 1946.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated February 22, 1960 made under s. 4-K of the P. Industrial Disputes Act 1946 the Government of U.P. referred to the Industrial Tribunal  1  at Allahabad for adjudication an industrial dispute alleged to exist between the appellant and its workmen on the following issues

facts.text: Dispute: whether employers wrongfully retired workmen (respondents 1-6 and Haider Ali) effective 1st August 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the employers have wrongfully arid or unjustifiably retired their workmen, mentioned in the Annexure, with effect from 1st August, 1959 ? If so, to what relief are the workmen entitled ? Respondents 1 to 6 and Haidcr Ali  since deceased  were the workmen mentioned in the Annexute.

facts.text: Workmen's case: entered service before certification, no retirement condition at appointment, practice to continue till physically fit.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the workmen before the Industrial Tribunal was that they had entered service of the appellant prior to the certification of the Standing Orders. At the time of their appointment there was numbercondition that they would be liable to retirement after attaining any prescribed age or after putting in any fixed period of service.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award May 2, 1960: employers within rights to retire workmen, not wrongful, no relief.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal made an award on May 2, 1960 finding, interalia,  a  the- employers were within their rights in retiring, the workmen companycerned.  b  The act of the employers in companypulsorily retiring the companycerned workmen,-from service companyld number be characterised as wrongful, illegal or unjustified and  c  the workmen were entitled to numberrelief.

facts.text: Bijli Mazdoor Sangh applied under s.10(2) on June 14, 1960 for amendment of clause 32 to fix retirement age at 60 years.

anchor.surface_text: On June 14, 1960 the Bijli Mazdoor Sangh moved an appli- cation under s. 10 2  of the Act for amendment and modifica- tion of clause 32 claiming fixation of retirement age at 60 years.

facts.text: Union filed writ petition in Allahabad High Court on September 20, 1960 to quash award.

anchor.surface_text: On September 20, 1960 the Union also filed a writ petition in the Allahabad High Court for quashing the award.

facts.text: Certifying Officer modified clause 32, fixed retirement age at 58 years on April 22, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1961 the Certifying Officer modified clause 32 and fixed the ago, of retirement at 58 years.

facts.text: Appellate authority refixed retirement age at 55 years on September 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1961 the appellate authority refixed the age of retirement at 55 years.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court on July 12, 1966 quashed the award, directed Tribunal to rehear.

anchor.surface_text: On July 12, 1966 the, High Court recorded an order quashing the award. It was held that Standing Order 32 was number applicable to the employees Who had entered service before the certification of the Standing Orders. The Industrial Tribunal was directed to reheat the case and after giving an opportunity to-the parties of being heard give an award in accordance with law.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award May 19, 1967: workmen wrongfully retired, deemed continued till September 16, 1964, pay wages to that date and retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Finally the award against which the appeal has- been brought was given on May 19, 1967. It was held in the award that all the seven workmen had been wrongfully and unjustifiably retired and that they should be deemed to have companytinued in service till September 16, 1964 from which date they would be taken to Wave been retrenched.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds clause 32 as certified in July 1951 invalid because no schedule item for retirement and pre-1956 s.4 no fairness adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that, clause 32 of the Standing Orders as certified in July 1951 was number valid and cannot be binding on the respondents.

facts.text: Modifications to clause 32 valid from April 22, 1961 after item 11-C introduced.

anchor.surface_text: The Certifying Officer, when lie modified clause 32 and AIR 1961 Mad. 107. fixed the,retiring age at 58 on April 22, 1961 companyld have validly certified such clause as modified by him.

facts.text: Supreme Court fixes retirement age at 58 years for these respondents.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the view that the age of superannuation of the respondents, in the present case, should be 58 years. In other words. it will be the same as was fixed by the Certifying Officer by modifying clause 32 on April 22, 1961.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, Tribunal award set aside, workmen entitled to wages till age 58.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the order of the Industrial Tribunal is hereby set aside. According to our decision the workmen companycerned companyld number have been retired on the ground of superannuation in accordance with clause 32 of the Standing Orders till it was certified after necessary modification on April 22, 1961.

issues.text: Whether the employers have wrongfully and/or unjustifiably retired their workmen, mentioned in the Annexure, with effect from 1st August, 1959? If so, to what relief are the workmen entitled?

Industrial Disputes Act 1946 the Government of U.P. referred to the Industrial Tribunal  1  at Allahabad for adjudication an industrial dispute alleged to exist between the appellant and its workmen on the following issues Whether the employers have wrongfully arid or unjustifiably retired their workmen,

issues.text: Whether certified Standing Orders are binding on workmen who were in employment at the time of certification or only on those employed thereafter, or whether uniformity of conditions of service requires them to apply to all workmen alike

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the view expressed therein that it was number intended by the legislature that different sets of companyditions should apply to employees depending on whether a workman was employed before the Standing Orders were certified or after, which would defeat the very object of the legislation.

arguments.claim: Certified Standing Orders clause 32 is not binding or enforceable on workmen who entered service prior to certification as there was no such retirement condition at appointment and practice was continuation till physically fit

anchor.surface_text: The case of the workmen before the Industrial Tribunal was that they had entered service of the appellant prior to the certification of the Standing Orders. At the time of their appointment there was numbercondition that they would be liable to retirement after attaining any prescribed age or after putting in any fixed period of service. A practice was in vogue that the workmen would companytinue in service till he was physically fit. Accordingly clause 32 of the certified Standing Orders was neither binding number enforceable.

holdings.text: Certified Standing Orders bind all workmen in employment at the time of certification and those employed thereafter to ensure uniformity of conditions of service

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the view expressed therein that it was number intended by the legislature that different sets of companyditions should apply to employees depending on whether a workman was employed before the Standing Orders were certified or after, which would defeat the very object of the legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of the Act, object to define precise uniform conditions for all employees, follows Agra Electric Supply and Salem Erode, distinguishes pre-1956 Guest Keen Williams

holdings.text: Clause 32 of the Standing Orders as certified in July 1951 was not valid and cannot be binding on the respondents

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that, clause 32 of the Standing Orders as certified in July 1951 was number valid and cannot be binding on the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No item in schedule covers retirement or superannuation (items 8/9 on termination/misconduct do not apply as superannuation automatic not by notice), pre-1956 s.4 no adjudication on fairness

holdings.text: After introduction of item 11-C, the Certifying Officer could validly certify modified clause 32 fixing retirement age at 58 years on April 22, 1961

anchor.surface_text: The Certifying Officer, when lie modified clause 32 and AIR 1961 Mad. 107. fixed the,retiring age at 58 on April 22, 1961 companyld have validly certified such clause as modified by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Item 11-C added via s.15 provides for superannuation/retirement, post-1956 s.4 allows fairness check

holdings.text: The age of superannuation of the respondents should be 58 years

anchor.surface_text: we are of the view that the age of superannuation of the respondents, in the present case, should be 58 years. In other words. it will be the same as was fixed by the Certifying Officer by modifying clause 32 on April 22, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances material evidence, appellate authority found 55 fair/reasonable, adopts Certifying Officer's 58 as appropriate despite later reduction to 55

holdings.text: The Allahabad High Court order of July 12, 1966 quashing the award and remanding is interlocutory and does not attract res judicata
holdings.reasoning_summary: Remand under Art. 227 does not finally terminate proceedings, follows Satyadhyan Ghosal distinguishing final writ orders

holdings.text: The employers did not wrongfully retire the workmen; they are entitled to wages till attaining age 58; appeal allowed, Tribunal award set aside

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the order of the Industrial Tribunal is hereby set aside. According to our decision the workmen companycerned companyld number have been retired on the ground of superannuation in accordance with clause 32 of the Standing Orders till it was certified after necessary modification on April 22, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid 1951 clause, valid post-1961 at 58, applies to all per uniformity; deems continuation till 58 with full wages adjustment

anchor.surface_text: Guest Keen, Williams Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling Others 1 . In that case after the enforcement of the Act the industrial companypany submitted its draft Standing Orders for certification to the Certifying Officer. That Officer certified the Standing Orders after giving the trade union of workmen an opportunity to be heard and after companysidering their objections. The Standing Orders relating to retirement provided that the workmen shall retire from the service of the companypany on reaching the age of 55 years.

precedents.case_name: Guest Keen Williams Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling Others
precedents.cited_proposition: Standing Orders certified subsequent to employment not applicable to existing employees for retirement age; Tribunal can adjudicate fairness and applicability
precedents.cited_holding: Workmen employed prior to certification not governed by retirement age in Standing Orders; retirement illegal

anchor.surface_text: Workmen of Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd. v. Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd. 1 . The next case in which a similar question arose in Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. v. Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. Employees Union 2 . It was claimed by the companypany which was the employer there that the urgent need for increased production and supply of electrical energy companyld be met if the existing rules embodied in two of its certified Standing Orders relating to holidays and leave were suitably amended.

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd. v. Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed the principle that pre-certification employees not bound by retirement provisions in Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. v. Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. Employees Union 2 . It was claimed by the companypany which was the employer there that the urgent need for increased production and supply of electrical energy companyld be met if the existing rules embodied in two of its certified Standing Orders relating to holidays and leave were suitably amended. The amendments proposed sought to introduce different rules relating to holidays and leave for employees who were appointed before a specified date and those who joined service after that date.

precedents.case_name: Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. v. Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. Employees Union
precedents.cited_proposition: No scope for separate Standing Orders for pre and post-certification employees; uniform conditions for all workmen
precedents.cited_holding: Standing Orders must be uniform and apply to all workmen alike

anchor.surface_text: Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Sri Alladin Ors.  2  one of the main questions was whether three workmen who had been employed long before 1951 when the companynpanys Standing Orders were certified companyld be retired under Standing Orderwhich prescribed the age of superannuation as 55 years. ThisCourt took a view which seemingly runs companynter to Guest KeenWilliams Pvt. Ltd. 1 .

precedents.case_name: Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Sri Alladin Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: Certified Standing Orders bind employers and all workmen in employment at the time of certification and thereafter as uniform conditions of service
precedents.cited_holding: Standing Orders apply to employees already in service at time of certification

anchor.surface_text: In Saroj Kumar Ghosh v. Orissa State Electricity Board 1  the Orissa High Court companysidered this question a some length and expressed the view that where a Standing Order has been certified by the Certifying Officer companytaining a clause relating to superannuation number companyered by the schedule of the Act numberr by the model Standing Orders such certification cannot be valid under S. 4 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Saroj Kumar Ghosh v. Orissa State Electricity Board
precedents.cited_proposition: Standing Order clause on superannuation not covered by schedule cannot be validly certified
precedents.cited_holding: Certification of superannuation clause invalid if not in schedule; termination of employment not equated with superannuation

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the learned single. judge in Management of the HINDU, Madras v. Secretary Hindu Office National Press Employees Union and another 2  was dissented from. In that case the expression termination of employment in item 8 was companysidered to be wide enough to include retirement of an employee at the age of superannuation. The learned Madras Judge sought support from para 16 of the model Standing Orders which is as follows Every permanent workman shall be entitled to a service certificate at the time of his dismissal discharge or retirement from service.

precedents.case_name: Management of the HINDU, Madras v. Secretary Hindu Office National Press Employees Union and another
precedents.cited_proposition: Termination of employment in schedule item 8 wide enough to include superannuation retirement

anchor.surface_text: Reliance has been placed on a decision of this Court in Management of Northern Railway Cooperative Society Ltd. v. Industrial Tribunal Rajasthan, Jaipur and Another 2 , where reference had been made by the State Government to the Industrial Tribunal on the Railway Workers Union having raised an industrial dispute against the Management of the Northern Railway Cooperative Society Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Management of Northern Railway Cooperative Society Ltd. v. Industrial Tribunal Rajasthan, Jaipur and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court dismissal of writ on competency bars plea by res judicata if no appeal filed
precedents.cited_holding: High Court writ order final; failure to appeal bars subsequent plea

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the case which is more apposite in Satyadhyan Ghosal Ors. v. Smt. Deorajin Debi Another   3   . There an order of remand had been made by the High Court while exercising powers under S. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. It was observed, after referring to the various decisions of the Privy Council, that the order of remand was interlocutory and number pumort to dispose of the case.

precedents.case_name: Satyadhyan Ghosal Ors. v. Smt. Deorajin Debi Another
precedents.cited_proposition: Interlocutory remand order does not attract res judicata; no need to appeal every interlocutory order
precedents.cited_holding: Remand order interlocutory, step towards final decision; no res judicata

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the order of the Industrial Tribunal is hereby set aside. According to our decision the workmen concerned could not have been retired on the ground of superannuation in accordance with clause 32 of the Standing Orders till it was certified after necessary modification on April 22,

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Industrial Tribunal's award set aside. Workmen deemed to have continued in service till attaining age of 58 years; entitled to full wages and dues till then; prior payments adjusted; no refund claim by appellant.
directions: Workmen deemed to have continued in service till age of 58 years.
Pay full wages and all other dues under terms of employment till age of 58 years.
Adjust any payments received pursuant to the award or after notice of termination.
Appellant undertakes not to claim refund of any excess amounts already received by workmen.
